title: Email Phising
desc: Can you help James avoid phising attempts?

thumbnail.alt: Photo by Mikhail Nilov from Pexels

winImg.alt: Photo by Andrea Piacquadio from Pexels

winText: After checking his emails, James reported the phishing attempts to the security team and continued with his work. A week later, he got the employee of the month award and was given a promotion. Now he lays back in his new office enjoying life.

scenes.text: This is James. He is an employee of company X with a unique sense of style. He rocks a turtleneck and a fedora in the middle of summer. He is on his way to his office to get the employee of the month award. He approaches the office with his sunglasses and was stopped by the guards in the exit. His outfit isn't allowed in.

As reluctant as he is, he changed his outfit back to his usual work uniform. He walks into his office, thinking about what he'll do with the award prize. He's sure he would win the award and get a promotion.
As he reaches his desk, he opens his laptop to check his emails. This is his daily work routine. Brimming with excitement, he opens the first email in his inbox.
It was an email from his manager. Looks like he'll get a bonus. A greedy grin appeared on James face.
scenes.question: Reply?
scenes.wrongText: James messed up real big this time. He gave his credentials and now his account is locked. Thankfully he reported to the security team and the damage didn't spread any further. He lost his chance of winning the award. James is sad.

scenes.text: Thankfully his brain still works. The email and his manager's name doesn't match. Moreover, why would his manager ask for his credentials. The bonus promised was laid as a trap for unsuspecting employees. James isn't that easy to fool. He opens another email
An email from a company James worked with a few weeks ago.
scenes.question: Open the form?
scenes.wrongText: James is now jobless as he entered his company's information unknowingly in the google form from the phishing link. He looks at the ground thinking what he could have done to avoid this.

scenes.text: The link in the form looks genuine at first, but upon closer inspection you can see the obvious forgery in it. 'google' doesn't end in 3, and links starting in 'http' should be clicked, as the connection is not secured. Thankfully, James is knowledgeable enough to spot this and avoid being tricked.
